Let $G$ be a graph with $2n+1$ vertices and $n^2+n+1$ edges. Must $G$ contain two vertices of the same degree which are joined by a path of length $3$?



A problem of Erd\H{o}s and Hajnal. The example of $K_{n,n+1}$ shows that this fails if we only have $n^2+n$ edges.

This is true, and was proved by Chen and Ma \cite{ChMa25}, who prove the stronger statement that, provided $n\geq 600$, all graphs with $2n+1$ vertices and at least $n^2+n$ edges contain two vertices of the same degree joined by a path of length $3$, except $K_{n,n+1}$.




References


[ChMa25] K. Chen and J. Ma, A problem of Erd\H{o}s and Hajnal on paths with equal-degree endpoints. arXiv:2503.19569 (2025).
